poem:
### Winter's Whisper

Spring, a distant promise whispered  
by snowdrops flirting with sunlight,  
while the lichen, a quiet congregation,   
graces the bark with ancient scrolls.  
In winter's chapel, beauty softens,  
a hushed hymn of stillness and patience,  
reminding the hurried heart  
to savor the steady grace of the season's hold.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Country diary: A copious display of lichen – how did it get here? | Phil Gates At last, meteorological spring is almost within touching distance. For most of February I’ve found myself searching for reassurance that it’s on the way; the first snowdrop, recklessly early hazel catkins, a precocious celandine. Then yesterday reminded me of the folly of wishing winter away, of being blind to the subtle beauty of the season. I’d come hoping to hear". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
